1.1_solids_liquids_gases.subtopic: Properties and Structure of Solids, Liquids and Gases

questions.question: Which statement about a solid, a liquid or a gas is correct?

options.A: A solid has a fixed shape and can be compressed.
options.B: A liquid takes the shape of the container it is in and can be compressed.
options.C: A solid has no fixed shape and cannot be compressed.
options.D: A gas takes the shape of the container it is in and can be compressed.

questions.explanation: Gases take the shape of their container and can be compressed due to large spaces between particles.

questions.question: Which statement about the molecules in ice, water or steam is correct?

options.A: The H2O molecules are on average closest together in steam.
options.B: The H2O molecules are on average furthest apart in water.
options.C: The H2O molecules in steam have the second highest average velocity.
options.D: The H2O molecules in ice are able to vibrate.

questions.explanation: In ice (solid), molecules can vibrate around fixed positions but cannot move freely.

questions.question: Which row describes the spacing and arrangement of particles in a solid, a liquid and a gas?

options.A: solid: close together and randomly arranged, liquid: close together and regularly arranged, gas: far apart and randomly arranged
options.B: solid: close together and randomly arranged, liquid: far apart and randomly arranged, gas: close together and randomly arranged
options.C: solid: close together and regularly arranged, liquid: close together and randomly arranged, gas: far apart and randomly arranged
options.D: solid: close together and regularly arranged, liquid: close together and regularly arranged, gas: close together and randomly arranged

questions.explanation: Solids have regular arrangements, liquids are close but random, gases are far apart and random.

questions.question: What are the processes X, Y and Z in the state changes shown: solid ←X→ liquid ←Y→ gas ←Z→ solid?

options.A: X: melting, Y: condensing, Z: evaporating
options.B: X: evaporating, Y: melting, Z: freezing
options.C: X: melting, Y: freezing, Z: condensing
options.D: X: freezing, Y: evaporating, Z: condensing

questions.explanation: X is melting (solid to liquid), Y is evaporating (liquid to gas), Z is sublimation (gas to solid).

questions.question: Which two diagrams show the states of matter before and after the sublimation of carbon dioxide?

options.B: 2 to 3

questions.explanation: Sublimation is the direct change from solid (3) to gas (1), skipping the liquid phase.

questions.question: What is the melting point of substance X from the heating curve showing temperature vs time?
questions.explanation: The melting point is where temperature remains constant during the phase change, shown as a horizontal line on the heating curve.

questions.question: Which row describes the cause of gas pressure and the effect of increasing temperature?

options.A: collisions between gas particles, collisions become less frequent
options.B: collisions between gas particles, the average speed of gas particles increases
options.C: collisions between gas particles and container, collisions become less frequent
options.D: collisions between gas particles and container, the average speed of gas particles increases

questions.explanation: Gas pressure is caused by particle collisions with container walls. Higher temperature increases particle speed.

questions.question: Between which times is substance M freezing on the cooling curve?

options.B: Q to R

questions.explanation: Freezing occurs when temperature remains constant as liquid changes to solid (horizontal section of cooling curve).

questions.question: In which changes of state is energy being given out?

options.B: 1 and 4

questions.explanation: Energy is given out during condensation (gas to liquid) and freezing (liquid to solid) as particles lose kinetic energy.

1.4_gas_behavior.subtopic: Effects of Temperature and Pressure on Gases

questions.question: A gas is heated from 50°C to 100°C in a sealed container. What happens to the gas particles?

options.B: They move faster and collide more frequently with the container

questions.explanation: Higher temperature increases particle kinetic energy, making them move faster and collide more frequently.

questions.question: Which statement about liquids and gases is correct?

options.A: 1 cm³ of gas contains more particles than 1 cm³ of liquid.
options.B: A given mass of liquid has a fixed volume at room temperature.
options.C: Particles in a liquid can easily be forced closer together.
options.D: Particles in a liquid have fixed positions.

questions.explanation: Liquids are incompressible and maintain fixed volume at constant temperature, unlike gases.

questions.question: The melting and boiling points of argon (-189°C, -186°C), nitrogen (-210°C, -196°C), and oxygen (-218°C, -183°C) are shown. At -200°C and 1 atm, how many samples are liquids?
questions.explanation: At -200°C: nitrogen (-210°C < -200°C < -196°C) and oxygen (-218°C < -200°C < -183°C) are liquids.

questions.question: What is diffusion?

options.A: The movement of particles from high to low concentration
options.B: The movement of particles from low to high concentration
options.C: The arrangement of particles in a regular pattern
options.D: The vibration of particles in fixed positions

questions.explanation: Diffusion is the net movement of particles down a concentration gradient.

questions.question: Which gas would diffuse fastest?

options.B: Oxygen (O₂)

questions.explanation: Lighter molecules diffuse faster. Hydrogen has the lowest molecular mass.

questions.question: Diffusion occurs faster in gases than in liquids because:

options.B: Gas particles are further apart and move faster

questions.explanation: Greater spaces between gas particles and higher kinetic energy allow faster diffusion.

questions.question: Which statement describes a compound?

options.A: It contains two or more elements chemically combined.
options.B: It contains two or more elements physically combined.
options.C: It contains two or more elements forming an alloy.
options.D: It contains two or more elements that can easily be separated.

questions.explanation: A compound is formed when two or more elements are chemically combined in fixed proportions.

questions.question: Which substance is a pure compound?

options.B: brass

questions.explanation: Ethanol (C₂H₅OH) is a pure compound. Air and petroleum are mixtures, brass is an alloy.

questions.question: Which row about elements, mixtures and compounds is correct?

options.A: metallic element: copper, non-metallic element: methane, mixture: brass, compound: sulfur
options.B: metallic element: brass, non-metallic element: sulfur, mixture: copper, compound: methane
options.C: metallic element: copper, non-metallic element: sulfur, mixture: brass, compound: methane
options.D: metallic element: brass, non-metallic element: methane, mixture: copper, compound: sulfur

questions.explanation: Copper is a metallic element, sulfur is non-metallic, brass is a mixture (alloy), methane is a compound.

questions.question: What are the relative charge and relative mass of an electron?

options.B: charge: 0, mass: 1/2000

questions.explanation: Electrons have -1 charge and negligible mass (approximately 1/2000 of a proton).

questions.question: Which statement about the noble gases is correct?

options.B: Noble gases are reactive gases.
options.C: Noble gases have full outer electron shells.
options.D: The noble gases are found on the left-hand side of the Periodic Table.

questions.explanation: Noble gases are unreactive because they have complete outer electron shells.

questions.question: Elements P and Q have the same number of electron shells. An atom of Q has more electrons in its outer shell than P. Which statements are correct?

options.A: 1 and 3: P and Q are in same group; P forms positive ions more easily
options.B: 1 and 4: P and Q are in same group; Q's oxide is more basic
options.C: 2 and 3: P and Q are in same period; P forms positive ions more easily
options.D: 2 and 4: P and Q are in same period; Q's oxide is more basic

questions.explanation: Same electron shells = same period. Q has more outer electrons so is more non-metallic, making P more metallic.

questions.question: Which pair of atoms contains the same number of neutrons?

options.B: ₂₉⁶⁴Cu and ₂₉⁶⁵Cu

questions.explanation: Cu-64: 64-29=35 neutrons, Zn-65: 65-30=35 neutrons. Same number of neutrons.

questions.question: Information about atoms X, Y and Z: X(1,1), Y(1,2), Z(1,3). Which statements are correct? 1) Isotopes of same element 2) Same number of electrons 3) Same number of neutrons 4) One occupied electron shell

options.B: 1 and 2 only

questions.explanation: All have 1 proton (same element), 1 electron each, and 1 electron shell. Different neutron numbers.

questions.question: Which statement about an atom of fluorine, ₉¹⁹F, is correct?

options.A: It contains a total of 28 protons, neutrons and electrons.
options.B: It contains more protons than neutrons.
options.C: Its isotopes contain different numbers of protons.

questions.explanation: ₉¹⁹F has 9 protons + 10 neutrons + 9 electrons = 28 total particles.

questions.question: Which statement about ions and ionic bonds is correct?

options.A: Bromine atoms form negatively charged bromide ions.
options.B: Ionic bonds form between elements in Group VII of the Periodic Table.
options.C: Positive ions are formed when atoms lose protons.
options.D: Potassium iodide contains negatively charged potassium ions.

questions.explanation: Bromine atoms gain electrons to form Br⁻ ions (bromide ions).

questions.question: Which statement describes the bonding in sodium chloride?

options.A: A shared pair of electrons between two atoms leading to a noble gas configuration.
options.B: A strong force of attraction between oppositely charged ions.
options.C: A strong force of attraction between two molecules.
options.D: A weak force of attraction between oppositely charged ions.

questions.explanation: Ionic bonding involves strong electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions.

questions.question: Elements X and Y react to form a compound. Element X loses two electrons and element Y gains one electron. What is the charge on the ions and formula of the compound?

options.A: charge on X: 2+, charge on Y: -, formula: X₂Y
options.B: charge on X: 2+, charge on Y: -, formula: XY₂
options.C: charge on X: 2-, charge on Y: +, formula: X₂Y
options.D: charge on X: 2-, charge on Y: +, formula: XY₂

questions.explanation: X loses 2 electrons → X²⁺, Y gains 1 electron → Y⁻. To balance: one X²⁺ needs two Y⁻ = XY₂.

questions.question: Which molecule has only two shared pairs of electrons?

options.B: Cl₂

questions.explanation: H₂O has two O-H bonds, each involving one shared pair of electrons, total = 2 shared pairs.

questions.question: Which row describes the formation of single covalent bonds in methane?

options.A: atoms share a pair of electrons, both atoms gain a noble gas electronic structure
options.B: atoms share a pair of electrons, both atoms have the same number of electrons in their outer shell
options.C: electrons are transferred from one atom to another, both atoms gain a noble gas electronic structure
options.D: electrons are transferred from one atom to another, both atoms have the same number of electrons in their outer shell

questions.explanation: Covalent bonding involves sharing electron pairs, allowing both atoms to achieve stable noble gas configurations.

questions.question: Which statement explains why graphite is used as a lubricant?

options.A: Each carbon atom in graphite forms three bonds.
options.B: The bonding in graphite is covalent.
options.C: The carbon atoms are arranged in hexagons.
options.D: There are weak forces of attraction between the layers of carbon atoms.

questions.explanation: Graphite can act as a lubricant because the layers can slide over each other due to weak van der Waals forces.

7.1_acid_base_properties.subtopic: Characteristic Properties of Acids and Bases

questions.question: Which two ions are involved in the neutralisation reaction between dilute hydrochloric acid and aqueous sodium hydroxide?

options.B: H⁺ and OH⁻

questions.explanation: Neutralisation involves the reaction H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O.

questions.question: Which statements about an aqueous acid are correct? 1) Ammonia formed with ammonium nitrate 2) Effervescence with sodium carbonate 3) Methyl orange turns yellow 4) Red litmus remains red

options.B: 1 and 4

questions.explanation: Acids cause effervescence with carbonates (CO₂ produced) and keep red litmus red.

questions.question: Which reaction produces ammonia gas?

options.A: warming ammonium chloride with dilute sodium hydroxide
options.B: warming ammonium nitrate with dilute sulfuric acid
options.C: warming ammonium phosphate with dilute sodium chloride
options.D: warming ammonium sulfate with dilute nitric acid

questions.explanation: Ammonium salts react with alkalis to produce ammonia gas: NH₄Cl + NaOH → NaCl + NH₃ + H₂O.

questions.question: Which indicator turns yellow when added to a solution with pH 14?

options.B: methyl orange

questions.explanation: Methyl orange turns yellow in alkaline solutions (high pH).

questions.question: Four solutions J, K, L, M show these universal indicator colors: green, red, purple, orange. Which solutions are acidic?

options.B: K and M

questions.explanation: Red and orange colors indicate acidic solutions on the universal indicator scale.

questions.question: The concentration of hydrogen ions in 0.1 mol/dm³ hydrochloric acid is higher than in 0.1 mol/dm³ ethanoic acid. Which statement explains this difference?

options.A: Ethanoic acid is an organic acid.
options.B: Ethanoic acid has a lower pH than hydrochloric acid.
options.D: Ethanoic acid is a strong acid.

questions.explanation: Ethanoic acid is a weak acid that only partially dissociates, producing fewer H⁺ ions than the strong acid HCl.

questions.question: Which equation represents the neutralisation of nitric acid using sodium hydroxide?

options.B: NaOH(aq) + HNO₃(aq) → NaNO₃(l) + H₂O(l)

questions.explanation: Neutralization: acid + base → salt + water. Correct state symbols: aqueous reactants, aqueous salt, liquid water.

questions.question: Which products are formed when magnesium hydroxide reacts with hydrochloric acid?

options.A: magnesium chloride, carbon dioxide and water
options.B: magnesium chloride, hydrogen and water

questions.explanation: Base + acid → salt + water. Mg(OH)₂ + 2HCl → MgCl₂ + 2H₂O.

questions.question: When an acid is added to an alkali, the temperature rises. Which words describe this reaction?

options.B: decomposition and exothermic

questions.explanation: Neutralization reactions are exothermic (release heat), causing temperature to rise.

questions.question: In the preparation of copper(II) sulfate crystals, why is filtration necessary?

options.B: to remove sulfuric acid

questions.explanation: Excess copper(II) oxide is used, so unreacted solid must be filtered out.

questions.question: Why is an excess of copper(II) carbonate added when preparing copper(II) sulfate?

options.A: to ensure all the copper(II) carbonate has reacted
options.B: to ensure all the sulfuric acid has reacted
options.C: to increase the rate of reaction
options.D: to increase the amount of copper(II) sulfate produced

questions.explanation: Excess solid reactant ensures all acid is consumed, preventing contamination with unreacted acid.

questions.question: Which processes are part of preparing solid copper(II) sulfate? 1) crystallisation 2) distillation 3) filtration 4) titration

options.B: 1 and 4

questions.explanation: Salt preparation involves filtration (remove excess reactant) and crystallisation (obtain pure crystals).

questions.question: Which element forms an acidic oxide?

options.B: lithium

questions.explanation: Sulfur is a non-metal that forms acidic oxides (SO₂, SO₃).

questions.question: The oxides of elements X and Y are dissolved in water. X gives pH 1, Y gives pH 13. Which information is correct?

options.A: X oxide acidic, Y oxide basic, X metal, Y non-metal
options.B: X oxide acidic, Y oxide basic, X non-metal, Y metal
options.C: X oxide basic, Y oxide acidic, X metal, Y non-metal
options.D: X oxide basic, Y oxide acidic, X non-metal, Y metal

questions.explanation: pH 1 = acidic oxide (from non-metal X), pH 13 = basic oxide (from metal Y).

questions.question: Which oxide is classified as amphoteric?

options.B: calcium oxide

questions.explanation: Aluminium oxide is amphoteric - it can react with both acids and bases.
